thread.title: Armour: Words aren't enough to capture Jake Arrieta's brilliance for Cubs
thread.title_full: Armour: Words aren't enough to capture Jake Arrieta's brilliance for Cubs

author: democratandchronicle.com
title: Armour: Words aren't enough to capture Jake Arrieta's brilliance for Cubs
text:
CHICAGO -- Even the Chicago Cubs have given up trying to find words or ways that can adequately describe Jake Arrieta’s brilliance. He’s 17-1 over his last 21 starts, including the Cubs’ first postseason win in 12 years. He hasn’t lost a game since July 25 and, even then, it took a no-hitter to do it. His 0.41 ERA from Aug. 4 to the end of the regular season is the lowest since Major League Baseball started keeping the stat way back in 1913.
“Wow. Wow,” Cubs catcher David Ross said Sunday, shaking his head as someone rattled off some of Arrieta’s best stats. “That’s unbelievable. It really is.
“That’s why we expect to win,” Ross continued. “When you have a guy go out there and win 99% of the time, you expect to win. And that’s a great thing.”
Just about anyone with a pulse knows the Cubs’ long, sad record of futility. No World Series title since 1908. A century marked by long stretches of losing seasons with the sporadic – and usually short -- postseason appearance thrown in.
But this Cubs team is different, this chance to finally end a 107-year-old curse feels different, and it’s in large part because of the guy who will be pitching against the St. Louis Cardinals in Game 3 of the NLDS on Monday.
USA TODAY
As Chase Utley debate rages, Cubs' Coghlan doesn't back down: 'No remorse'
“I'm confident in my ability to go out there tomorrow and give us an outing that's good enough to win the game,” Arrieta said. “Obviously on their side, (Michael) Wacha has got the ability to be pretty darned good on the mound himself. I just intend to keep us in the game, regardless of the circumstances, whatever comes up.
“But I like my chances to go out there and win us a ballgame.”
Just as there is no good way to describe Arrieta’s dominance, there’s no good way to explain it, either.
Arrieta has always had the makings of an ace – he was Baltimore’s opening-day starter in 2012 – but could never put it all together until this season, when he refined what Ross describes as his “cutter-slash-slider” and others have called his “slutter.” It’s a devilishly deceptive pitch because it never, ever looks exactly the same, and hitters can see it change before their eyes depending upon which side of the plate the ball’s on.
Add in a fastball that still moves at upwards of 94 mph, a solid changeup, and a breaking ball that Ross says is one of the best he’s ever seen, and you can understand why the Cubs believe any game Arrieta pitches is one for their win column.
But Arrieta’s emergence as baseball’s scariest pitcher isn’t all due to technique. Struggles early in his career have made him preternaturally calm. While the hype and expectations might fluster other pitchers, Arrieta gets more focused.
Seriously. What other pitcher throws a no-hitter and then shows up for the postgame news conference in a moustache onesie ?
“I've had some pretty dark times in this game, in my career,” Arrieta said. “I've had some pretty tough ones, so I don't think anything bothers me anymore.”
USA TODAY
Nightengale: Cubs tie Cardinals in NLDS - but it feels like 2-1 already
Taking their lead from Joe Cool Maddon, the Cubs have been loose all season, refusing to live down to their expectations or cower at curses. You want to talk billy goats and black cats? Maddon will raise you one and bring a zoo to Wrigley Field. (If you haven’t seen the photos already, Google them. They’re fantastic.)
But the postseason is a different atmosphere altogether, especially for a team as young as the Cubs. Knowing they have an ace who is as unflappable as he is unhittable makes up for all manner of sins, to say nothing of easing rookie jitters.
“There’s never any panic when your guy’s been so dominant for so long,” Ross said.
Baseball, more than any other sport it seems, turns on luck and chance.
A team can be streaking toward the pennant only to have a black cat appear (Cubs, 1969). A perennial contender can be seemingly in control of a game, and a series, only to completely unravel with a throwing error (St. Louis, Saturday night). A player can be dominant for the entire regular season, only to come undone in the playoffs (Clayton Kershaw, David Price).
Sure, there’s the chance Arrieta becomes one of those flukes, the latest chapter in the Cubs’ tragicomedy.
But it’s unlikely. He didn’t have his best stuff in the wild-card against Pittsburgh, hitting two batters, but he still blanked the Pirates on five hits.
“We all know anything can happen in the playoffs,” Ross said. “(But) I have a strong, strong gut feeling he’s going to pitch really well. Just a little bit of a feeling right here that says he’s going to do a great job and we’re going to play well and we’re going to win the game.”
Words can’t do justice to what Arrieta’s done these last four months, but they don’t need to. The numbers in the win column say it all.
PHOTOS: MLB POSTSEASON HIGHLIGHTS
ALDS, Game 3: Blue Jays vs. Rangers: Troy Tulowitzki smashes a three-run home run in the 6th inning to give the Blue Jays a 5-0 lead. Tim Heitman, ALDS Game 3: Astros vs. Royals -- After setting a record for most wins by pitcher who went unbeaten at home in a season, Astros ace Dallas Keuchel improves on his 15-0 ledger at Minute Maid Park this year. Thomas Shea, NLDS Game 2: Mets vs. Dodgers -- SS Ruben Tejada collides with Chase Utley at second base in the seventh inning. Jayne Kamin-Oncea, NLDS Game 2: Mets vs. Dodgers - Rookie Michael Conforto hits a laser off Zack Greinke for a home run that had an exit velocity of 115 mph. Jayne Kamin-Oncea, NLDS Game 2: Cubs vs. Cardinals. Cubs shortstop Addison Russell squares for a suicide squeeze in the second inning -- the second of the inning. Jeff Curry, \ NLDS Game 2: Cubs vs. Cardinals - Matt Carpenter leads off the game with s solo home run. Jasen Vinlove, NLDS Game 1: Mets vs. Dodgers - David Wright's two-run single in the 7th inning gives the Mets a 3-0 lead. Richard Mackson, NLDS Game 1: Mets vs. Dodgers - Jacob deGrom strikes out 13 batters, which ties Tom Seaver for most strikeouts by a Mets pitcher in postseason history. Jayne Kamin-Oncea, NLDS Game 1: Cubs vs. Cardinals - Cardinals rookie Tommy Pham, a career minor leaguer, homers in his first postseason game, 431 feet. Scott Rovak, NLDS Game 1: Cubs vs. Cardinals - John Lackey, who took a no-hitter into the six inning, allows just two hits over 7 1/3 innings. Scott Rovak, ALDS Game 2: Astros vs. Royals - Astros' Colby Rasmus hits a home run against the Royals -- his third homer in three straight postseason games. Peter Aiken, ALDS Game 2: Rangers vs. Blue Jays - Blue Jays slugger Josh Donaldson get into a shouting match with Rangers reliever Keone Kela in the 13th inning, causing the benches and benches to briefly empty. Nick Turchiaro, ALDS Game 2: Rangers vs. Blue Jays - Hansel Alberto, not pictured, lines a 14th-inning, game-winning single to center, plating Rougned Odor, pictured, as the Rangers take a 2-0 series lead over the Blue Jays. . Nick Turchiaro, ALDS Game 2: Rangers vs. Blue Jays - Rougned Odor makes an elusive slide past the tag of Blue Jays catcher Russell Martin in the second inning to give the Rangers a 3-1 lead. Dan Hamilton, ALDS Game 1: Astros vs. Royals - Center fielder Jake Marisnick makes a diving catch in the fifth inning to rob Royals' Elcides Escobar. John Rieger, ALDS Game 1: Rangers vs. Blue Jays - Rougned Odor (right) celebrates with Delino DeShields after hitting a solo home run in the 7th inning to give the Rangers a deciding 5-3 lead. Nick Turchiaro, NL wild-card game: The Cubs celebrate their first postseason win since the 2003 NLCS after defeating the Pirates 4-0. Charles LeClaire, NL wild-card game: Jake Arrieta becomes the first Cubs pitcher to throw a postseason shutout in 70 years, leading the Cubs to a 4-0 victory. Charles LeClaire, NL wild-card game: Cubs rookie Kyle Schwarber rounds the bases after hitting a majestic 450-foot two-run homer that landed in the Allegheny River in the third inning off Pirates' Gerrit Cole. Charles LeClaire, NL wild-card game: Cubs starter Jake Arrieta reacts after he was hit by a pitch by Pirates' Tony Watson in the seventh inning. "It’s the playoffs.There’s a lot at stake. Tempers are running hot. It’s just the environment. It breeds that kind of intensity, and sometimes those things happen." Charles LeClaire, AL wild-card game: On three days rest, Dallas Keuchel hurls six shutout innings of three-hit, seven-strikeout ball in Houston’s 3-0 victory over the Yankees. Adam Hunger, AL wild-card game: Astros outfielder Carlos Gomez hits a home run on the first pitch of the fourth inning off Yankees' Masahiro Tanaka that sails deep into the left field stands, silencing the capacity crowd. Appropriately, Gomez flips his bat and admires it. Adam Hunger,
